meanings.def: very good or pleasant
examples: He's a great bloke.
What a great goal!
We had a great time in Madrid.
You should have come along. It was great fun.
You've done a great job.
I think that's a great idea.
It's a great way to meet new people.
New Zealand is a great place to live.
This is a great opportunity for us.
He missed a great chance to score in the final minutes of the match.
it is great to do something It's great to see you again.
great with somebody/something He's great with the kids.
‘Why don't we order a pizza?’ ‘That sounds great.’
‘I'll pick you up at seven.’ ‘That'll be great, thanks.’
(ironic) Oh great, they left without us.
We had a great time in Madrid.
I think their new song’s really cool.
‘How was your holiday?’ ‘Fantastic!’
Jane’s a fabulous cook.
She’s doing a terrific job.
‘How was the show?’ ‘Brilliant!’
The show was just awesome.
The adventure and action are truly epic in scope.
The food smells absolutely great.
You're a great cook—this is delicious!
That's really great news!

meanings.def: much more than average in degree or quantity
examples: This is a matter of great importance.
The lack of clean drinking water is of great concern.
The concert had been a great success.
Her death was a great shock to us all.
It gives me great pleasure to welcome you here today.
We will be following his progress with great interest.
one of the greatest challenges facing the world today
These women represent a group at greater risk of developing particular cancers.
Take great care of it.
You've been a great help.
(ironic) You've been a great help, I must say (= no help at all).
We are all to a great extent the products of our culture.
The problem is treated in great detail in the book.
Grate the apples and carrots and add to the mixture.
A small fire was burning in the grate.
She is a young player with great potential.
The play was a very great success.
Don't worry. It's no great problem.
They examined the figures in great detail.

meanings.def: very large; much bigger than average in size or quantity
examples: A great crowd had gathered.
People were arriving in great numbers.
The great majority of (= most) people seem to agree with this view.
He must have fallen from a great height.
She lived to a great age.

meanings.def: used to emphasize an adjective of size or quality
examples: There was a great big pile of books on the table.
He cut himself a great thick slice of cake.
There's a great big hole in this sleeve.
a large amount of
a large number of
a large quantity of
a great deal of
in great detail
a person of great age.

meanings.def: extremely good in ability or quality and therefore admired by many people
examples: Gary Kasparov, undoubtedly the greatest chess player of all time
He has been described as the world's greatest violinist.
Sherlock Holmes, the great detective
Great art has the power to change lives.
This represents a great achievement.
He was a truly great man.

meanings.def: important and impressive
examples: The wedding was a great occasion.
This is a great day for the city of Chicago.
The great thing is to get it done quickly.
One great advantage of this metal is that it doesn't rust.

meanings.def: having high status or a lot of influence
examples: the great powers (= important and powerful countries)
We can make this country great again.
Alexander the Great

meanings.def: in a very good state of physical or mental health
examples: She seemed in great spirits (= very cheerful).
I feel great today.
I don’t feel too great.
Everyone's in great form.
You're looking great. Marriage must suit you!

meanings.def: able to do something well
examples: She's great at chess.

meanings.def: very suitable or useful for something
examples: great for doing something This gadget's great for opening jars.
great for something Try this cream—it's great for spots.

meanings.def: used when you are emphasizing a particular description of somebody/something
examples: We are great friends.
I've never been a great reader (= I do not read much).
She's a great talker, isn't she?
I am a great admirer of your work.

meanings.def: added to words for family members to show a further stage in relationship
examples: my great-aunt (= my father’s or mother’s aunt)
her great-grandson (= the grandson of her son or daughter)
my great-great-grandfather (= the grandfather of my grandfather)

meanings.def: used in the names of animals or plants that are larger than similar kinds
examples: the great tit

meanings.def: used with the name of a city to describe an area that includes the centre of the city and a large area all round it
examples: Greater London

meanings.def: to be doing something quickly and successfully
examples: Work is going great guns now.

meanings.def: to be better or more effective as a group than you would think just by looking at the individual members of the group
examples: The team is greater than the sum of its parts.

meanings.def: to do something a lot; to enjoy something
examples: He's never been a great one for keeping in touch.
You're a great one for quizzes, aren't you?

meanings.def: to be not very good, efficient, suitable, etc.
much; a lot
examples: She's feeling a good deal better.
We don't see them a great deal (= often) these days.
They spent a great deal of money.
A good deal of research has been done on the subject.

meanings.def: people who are very successful, admired and respected
examples: Universities around the world award honorary degrees to the great and the good.

meanings.def: of all sizes or types
examples: all creatures great and small

meanings.def: used to refer to where a particular person is imagined to go when they die or a thing when it is no longer working, similar to the place they were connected with on earth
examples: Their pet rabbit had gone to the great rabbit hutch in the sky.

meanings.def: used to say that you and another person must both be very clever because you have had the same idea or agree about something
something large and successful often begins in a very small way
to put a lot of effort into doing something
examples: The couple went to great pains to keep their plans secret.

meanings.def: to do something very carefully
examples: He always takes great pains with his lectures.

idioms.def: to be doing something quickly and successfully
examples: Work is going great guns now.

idioms.idiom: be greater/more than the sum of its parts
idioms.def: to be better or more effective as a group than you would think just by looking at the individual members of the group
examples: The team is greater than the sum of its parts.

idioms.idiom: be a great one for (doing) something
idioms.def: to do something a lot; to enjoy something
examples: He's never been a great one for keeping in touch.
You're a great one for quizzes, aren't you?

idioms.def: to be not very good, efficient, suitable, etc.

examples: She's feeling a good deal better.
We don't see them a great deal (= often) these days.
They spent a great deal of money.
A good deal of research has been done on the subject.

idioms.def: people who are very successful, admired and respected
examples: Universities around the world award honorary degrees to the great and the good.
all creatures great and small

idioms.def: used to refer to where a particular person is imagined to go when they die or a thing when it is no longer working, similar to the place they were connected with on earth
examples: Their pet rabbit had gone to the great rabbit hutch in the sky.

idioms.def: used to say that you and another person must both be very clever because you have had the same idea or agree about something

idioms.idiom: great/tall oaks from little acorns grow
idioms.def: something large and successful often begins in a very small way

idioms.idiom: take (great) pains (to do something) | go to great pains (to do something)
idioms.def: to put a lot of effort into doing something
examples: The couple went to great pains to keep their plans secret.
He always takes great pains with his lectures.

meanings.def: a very well-known and successful person
examples: He was one of boxing's all-time greats.

meanings.def: very well
examples: Well done. You did great.
